summary: This is an FBI 302 interview report of a Bureau of Prisons Senior Officer Specialist, conducted on August 29, 2019, regarding her duties and observations at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 10, 2019, the day of Jeffrey Epstein's death. The interviewee describes standard operating procedures for head counts, door controls, and her actions in response to the medical emergency alarm.

persons.name: Llewellyn Jestin Anthony
persons.context: FBI agent who drafted the FD-302 interview report on September 4, 2019.

persons.name: Thomas
persons.context: Correctional Officer who worked in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on the day of the incident (August 10, 2019). The interviewee later reached out to him to check on his well-being.

connections.description: Anthony drafted the report containing the interview where CO Thomas's activities on the day of the incident are discussed.

events.title: Epstein Death Incident at MCC
events.description: The day Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The interviewee was working the 'Control 1' shift from midnight to 8 A.M. and describes the procedures and her response to the medical emergency alarm at approximately 6:33 A.M.

events.title: Interview of BOP Officer
events.description: An interview was conducted with a Bureau of Prisons Senior Officer Specialist regarding the events and procedures at MCC on August 10, 2019.

locations: 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The interviewee, a BOP Senior Officer Specialist, was working the 'Control 1' shift from midnight to 8 A.M. on August 10, 2019, the day Jeffrey Epstein died.
Standard procedure involved head counts at 12:00, 3:00, and 5:00 A.M., with counts verified and marked on 'E1' sheets. The SHU count on the day of the incident was reported as '72' and was accurate.
The video feed for viewing the rest of the range in the SHU was not operational during the interviewee's shift.
The medical emergency body alarm was hit at approximately 6:33 A.M., prompting the interviewee to immediately call 911/EMS.
Correctional Officer Thomas was buzzed out of the SHU after EMS arrived on scene.
